evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as per the historical dynamic understanding prior to preliminary analysis.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident withstands challenges and alternative explanations based on the historical dynamic data prior to preliminary analysis.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and coordination lapses documented in the preliminary dynamic history.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential defeaters, supported by consistent evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary dataset.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic understanding preliminary dataset, reflecting typical patterns and anomalies relevant to pushback procedures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as per the historical dynamic understanding prior to preliminary analysis.

assumptions: The documented interactions reflect the overall communication and coordination state among crew during the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or if the incident was caused solely by procedural deviation unrelated to communication.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents communication and coordination actions and failures among crew and tug operators, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the continued movement beyond TRP was due to communication failure or procedural deviation

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and coordination lapses documented in the preliminary dynamic history.

assumptions: The described interactions reflect coordination and communication lapses relevant to the incident.
The continued movement beyond the TRP indicates a breakdown in coordination or communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without lapses or miscommunication.
If the incident was caused primarily by procedural deviation unrelated to communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents communication and coordination interactions among crew and tug operators, including a trainee stopping pushback and instructor taking over, and the aircraft moving beyond the tug release point causing a collision, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
